Arsene Wenger denies retirement but unsure over football management return

Arsene Wenger is unsure over a return to football management but insists he is not retired after leaving Arsenal in the summer.

"To be honest, for the moment, I have not really thought about that because I fixed myself something whereby in the first few months I would not take any decisions," L'Est Republicain.

"So I have not been too worried about that. It is not even going through my head.

He added: "No, I am not retired. If I was I would have been for a long time. I will be 69 in October.

Asked if he would take another managerial role, Wenger replied: "I don’t know, I don’t know."

Barcelona are unlikely to make an approach for Manchester United midfielder Paul Pogba after learning of the France international’s wage demands, reports Mundo Deportivo.

LEWANDOWSKI: I HAD OFFERS TO LEAVE

Bayern Munich striker Robert Lewandowski has claimed he turned down the chance to leave the Allianz Arena in the summer, with Chelsea and Real Madrid among the clubs keen on signing him.

The Poland international was linked with a move to Stamford Bridge, with the Blues seeking to add goals to the squad due to Alvaro Morata's difficult first season in England.

"I have received several from different clubs and I have spoken openly," Lewandowski told Sportowe Fakty.

"I knew, regardless of the offer, that the club’s response would always be no. I did not like some things between me and Bayern, I had to clear it up first.

"Now I’m fine here and I can not speak of disappointment because I’m in one of the biggest clubs in the world."

IBRA BACK ITALY?

AC Milan sporting director Leonardo confirmed that the club have also "thought about" signing Zlatan Ibrahimovic, who joined LA Galaxy this season and has a contract through the 2019 season.

Ibrahimovic played for city AC Milan from 2010 to 2012, winning a Serie A title with the club, before moving to Paris Saint-Germain.

"It's normal that there's a personal connection with him. When we first arrived we thought about it, even at the age of 37 he can drive a team," said Leonardo.

"Right now the transfer window is closed, we have to do things calmly and not forget that there are some Financial Fair Play stakes. We want to build a competitive team."

Adrien Rabiot leaning towards staying at PSG after all

PSG midfielder Adrien Rabiot’s contract is set to expire at the end of this season, but he has made it clear to individuals inside the club’s training ground that his preference is to remain at the club and sign a new deal, according to L’Équipe.

There are multiple reasons for this:

1 | His obvious attachment to PSG, having grown up under the QSI regime and the club’s youth academy with the same youth coaches as Kimpembe, Coman and M.Dembélé.

2 | His relationship with a variety of PSG staff is excellent. Rabiot feels like the child of PSG.

3 | He has a very strong base of friends and family in Saint-Germain-en-Laye, where he currently resides.

4 | Adrien Rabiot believes that he can genuinely make improvements to his game under the tutelage of PSG boss Thomas Tuchel.

Barcelona have no plans to re-sign Neymar, says vice-president Jordi Cardoner

Barcelona have no plans to re-sign Neymar from Paris Saint-Germain, the club's vice-president Jordi Cardoner has said, dismissing media reports they were ready to tempt the Brazil forward back to the Nou Camp.

"No one on the Barca board has talked about the possibility of bringing back Neymar, right now we can't give an answer because no one has even mentioned it," Cardoner told radio station SER Catalunya on Friday.

"He was the one who left, it would be different if we hadn't believed him and now we wanted to bring him back, but that's not the case," Cardoner added.

"If we did want to sign him then the board would have to discuss it but until now no one has talked about it."

Pablo Zabaleta eyes Middle East career finale

“My heart tells me I would like to play forever, but I will be 34 in January and I need to listen to my body at that time,” he told Arab News.

“At the end I will know what I want to do and where to go, but I would like one or two more years to carry on playing. At 34 I think it might be the right time to try something different, have a new experience.

“If I carry on playing in Europe, Italy is one of those leagues I haven’t played, but I have always been thinking about the Middle East. I first went to the UAE for the Under-20 World Cup in 2003 and have seen how much the region has changed.

“I’ve been to Saudi Arabia and Qatar with the national team and you see the fantastic progress, football standards improving and passion of fans.

“The League is not as long as in Europe, but there’s still the chance to play for trophies, to play big games competitively like in the Asian Champions League.

“I can’t see myself going to China; the Middle East and America are more attractive.

Liverpool FC is quietly on the market

John Henry, the billionaire owner of the Boston Red Sox, has quietly signaled he’s willing to sell his other trophy sports franchise, the UK-based soccer team Liverpool FC, The Post has learned.

Henry — who on Oct. 28 was busy popping champagne as the Red Sox beat the Los Angeles Dodgers to win the World Series — is running a “passive sales process” for Liverpool, according to a source close to the situation.

That means Henry is privately entertaining offers in an informal process that’s outside of an official auction — and is looking for a price well north of $2 billion, the source added.

“It’s for sale if he can get the right price,” the source close to the situation said.

Two other sources also said Liverpool is essentially for sale.

Reps for Henry, who bought Liverpool for $477 million in 2010, didn’t respond to calls for comment.

https://nypost.com/2018/11/08/liverpool-fc-is-quietly-on-the-market/

Five Premier League clubs, including Chelsea, face threat of transfer ban as part of Fifa investigation | @Matt_Law_DT

Five Premier League clubs are facing the threat of being hit with a transfer ban as part of Fifa’s investigation into the signing of foreign players under the age of 18.

Chelsea are one of the clubs and a report by French investigative website Mediapart has claimed that Fifa’s Integrity and Compliance unit have internally proposed a two-year transfer ban on the London club stretching across four windows.

But sources close to the Fifa investigation have told Telegraph Sport that Chelsea are not the only Premier League club facing the possibility of a transfer ban. “This a massive investigation that will implicate a number of clubs,” said the source. “It will touch most of the big clubs around Europe and in the Premier League.”

It is believed at least four other Premier League clubs are under investigation and some of the biggest clubs in Europe are also being looked into.

Exclusive: English youngsters like Jadon Sancho could be denied foreign moves to boost careers after Brexit

Britain's most promising young footballers could be denied moves to foreign clubs after Brexit, Telegraph Sport can reveal.

An investigation by this newspaper has discovered that players such as Jadon Sancho - whose form with Borussia Dortmund after moving there aged 17 has seen him elevated to the England squad - would have been prevented from moving if Britain had already withdrawn from the European Union.

Under current Fifa rules, it is forbidden for players under 18 to be sold to overseas clubs. The only exceptions are for players aged 16 and 17, who are allowed to move within countries in the European Economic Area.

Telegraph Sport understands that the future eligibility of British players abroad is currently a matter of serious concern for bodies such as the Football Association and Professional Footballers' Association.

NARROW VOTE FOR WINDOW CLOSURE

Premier League clubs chose by the narrowest of margins to close next summer’s transfer window on the eve of the new season, SSN has learnt.

The 20 clubs voted by 11 votes to nine in favour of sticking with a shortened window, rather than having deadline day on August 31.

In 2017, PL clubs voted to close the summer’s window three weeks early on August 9, rather than allow transfer comings and goings to affect clubs as the new campaign got underway.

SSN understands that after lengthy discussions, the defining factor in last week’s negotiations was that as many as FOUR Premier League matches would have been played after the start of the 2019/2020 season, whilst the window remained open.

Clubs also discussed the fact that last summer’s window was adversely affected by players and clubs focussing on the World Cup, rather than on domestic transfer business.

SALARY CAPS IN CHINA

Clubs in the Chinese Super League (CSL) will be required to adhere to a new set of regulations from next season, including a player salary cap to prevent them from splurging on fees.

The China Football Association (CFA) has taken various measures in recent years to discourage wastefulness by top-flight clubs, who have spent vast sums to lure high-profile overseas players and coaches to the country.

As part of the new regulations, the CFA would introduce restrictions on cash injections for clubs, as well as player bonuses, transfer fees and salaries, according to state news agency Xinhua.

Leicester City begin 'respectful' talks over futures of out of contract players

Conversations have started over the futures of some of Leicester City’s players coming to the end of their contracts, but manager Claude Puel said now was not the time to discuss their situations publicly.

Captain Wes Morgan and fellow defenders Christian Fuchs, Danny Simpson and Yohan Benalouane, plus striker Shinji Okazaki, are all out of contract at the end of this season and City may consider allowing them to leave during the January transfer window, but while Puel has admitted director of football Jon Rudkin has begun talks with the players behind the scenes, he said he wanted to keep his players focused now on a busy period of games in which many of them will feature.

“There’s some discussions with Jon (Rudkin) about all the players in our squad,” said Puel.

“I don’t want to give it away for them or for other players. I can say about them, about the squad, I’m happy to have all these players with us. We have to manage them and try to give them the game-time to continue with a positive attitude.

“My feelings are there will be a time to discuss the future of different players, but now is not the time.”

BAYERN DENY WENGER CONTACT

Bayern Munich’s sporting director Hasan Salihamidzic has confirmed there has been no contact with Arsene Wenger and that manager Niko Kovac will remain in place for the next Bundesliga game against Werder Bremen.

Sources in Germany on Tuesday told Sky Sports that there had been no contact with the ex-Arsenal boss and that he was eyeing an executive role anyway, rather than another managerial post.

LOAN CHANGES EDGING CLOSER

Sky Sports News understands that FIFA’s proposals to change loan deal rules are edging closer and could come in to effect as soon as the 2020 season.

FIFA has been in contact with clubs like Chelsea who have as many as 40 players out on loan at the moment. But there is some suggestion that the new rules might not apply to domestic loans or home grown academy players.

Reports out today suggest the proposals have already been ratified. But Sky Sports News understands that’s not the case and that FIFA will vote on them in the new year.

It’s understood the proposals would limit clubs to loaning 6 to 8 players per season. FIFA said: “The said package includes, among others, the development of the regulation of loans of players for the purpose of youth development as opposed to commercial exploitation. The number of loans per season and between each club shall be limited and bridge transfers and sub-loans shall be prohibited”.

PETER BOSZ TAKES OVER AS COACH FROM HEIKO HERRLICH


Bayer 04 have parted company with head coach Heiko Herrlich. The Bundesliga club has released the 47-year-old as well as his assistant coach Nico Schneck with immediate effect. Herrlich's successor as the Werkself coach is the Dutchman Peter Bosz who will take up his post on 4 January 2019 for the start of preparations for the second half of the season.

The 54-year-old, who took Ajax through to the Europa League final against Manchester United in 2017, has signed a contract to 30 June 2020. Bosz will be joined at Leverkusen by his assistant coach Hendrik 'Hendrie' Krüzen.

"Heiko Herrlich gave our team an important boost last year after a very difficult season and he took us into Europe. We were convinced and determined to turn the corner with him as head coach. Unfortunately, there has been an undeniable stagnation in the development of the team. Even though we are within reach of the European positions at the end of the year we find ourselves in a situation after a less than satisfactory first half of the season that makes a change of coach essential from our point of view," said Rudi Völler as sporting managing director in explaining the decision.

"With Peter Bosz as manager we want to get back to meeting our ambitious targets as quickly as possible," declared the Bayer 04 chairman Fernando Carro. "Of course, that is also down to the players. They have to consistently show their undoubted ability, which unfortunately has rarely been evident over the past six months."

In the view of Bayer 04 sporting director Simon Rolfes, Peter Bosz wants to play "Attacking, high tempo and exciting football. He has always demonstrated particular passion in working with young players wherever he has coached. Therefore, Peter is an excellent fit here with us as we have placed great emphasis on developing highly talented youth players and bringing them through to the top level in a balanced combination with experienced pros for many years. Our team will benefit from having Peter Bosz as our coach," declared Rolfes. "Particularly at Ajax, he demonstrated he can improve young players, build teams and also compete on the European stage."

https://www.bayer04.de/en-us/news/bayer04/peter-bosz-takes-over-as-coach-from-heiko-herrlich

AS Monaco on the offensive to bring in Mamadou Sakho

Monaco are also seeking to sign an experienced central defender this January and in this vein they have stepped up their chase for French international central defender Mamadou Sakho, according to L’Équipe.

Gary Cahill (33 – Chelsea) has decided not to come to Monaco, Pepe (35 – free) wants his next move to be in Portugal for family reasons and negotiations with Nantes for Brazilian central defender Diego Carlos have been largely called off owing to the considerable fee that Les Canaris have been asking for.

Now, Monaco turn to Crystal Palace defender Mamadou Sakho, with VP Vadim Vasilyev willing to put up a hefty fee in order to land the former PSG man. Thierry Henry has given the go-ahead that he appreciates the player and would like to see him in his squad as soon as possible.

Negotiations are ongoing.

Milan - Brazilian midfielder Lucas Paqueta has arrived in Italy ahead of completing a record transfer move to AC Milan, Italian media reported on Sunday.

"I'm very happy to be here, I chose Milan because of their history," Paqueta told journalists at the airport.

The Serie A giants are reported to have agreed a €35 million deal with Flamengo - the club Paqueta joined as a 10-year-old - in what would be the most expensive signing of a Brazilian by an Italian club.

Paqueta scored 10 goals to help Flamengo finish second in the Brazilian championship which has just ended, and bid a tearful farewell after his last game at the Maracana Stadium.

AFP

STOKE SPLASH £20M ON WOODS & AFOBE

Stoke have today spent just under £20m on the permanent signings of Ryan Woods and Benik Afobe, who are both on loan at the Bet365 Stadium, Sky Sports News has learned.

No club involved in the deals has published the fees involved, but we understand Brentford will get £7m for Woods and Stoke will pay Wolves £12m for Afobe, who has scored seven times this season.

Woods has been a regular part of Stoke’s midfield, with 21 appearances so far this season.

The news is a boost for manager Gary Rowett, who has come under increased pressure from some fans, after Stoke managed just one win in five over Christmas.

CELTIC JOIN BURKE RACE

It’s thought the Baggies would be prepared to listen to offers on a permanent deal for Burke, who cost them £15m when he signed from RB Leipzig 18 months ago, but that a loan move is more likely at this stage.

It is also believed Brendan Rodgers is looking for two forwards in this window, and he sees Burke as a good creative option.

quote.msg:
CELTIC JOIN BURKE RACE

Sky Sports News understands Celtic are one of a number of clubs interested in taking West Brom winger Oliver Burke on loan for the rest of the season.

Burke hasn’t started a Championship match this season under Darren Moore, who is keen to get him some game time elsewhere.

It’s thought the Baggies would be prepared to listen to offers on a permanent deal for Burke, who cost them £15m when he signed from RB Leipzig 18 months ago, but that a loan move is more likely at this stage.

It is also believed Brendan Rodgers is looking for two forwards in this window, and he sees Burke as a good creative option.

Schalke show interest in Napoli midfielder Marko Rog

Schalke are interested in a loan deal for Napoli’s Marko Rog, according to Kicker.

The German outlet states that Schalke will have an option to make the deal permanent once the loan is over, while Napoli will have a buy-back option.

Schalke have looked to strengthen their midfield this season with Sebastian Rudy, Suat Serdar and Omar Mascarell all arriving as midfield reinforcements in the summer.

Should Rog sign for the Royal Blues, it could signal trouble for some of Schalke’s more fringe players – who may be shown the door this winter.

https://www.getfootballnewsgermany.com/2019/schalke-show-interest-in-napoli-midfielder-marko-rog/

James Rodríguez’ entourage are pushing for a transfer away from Bayern Munich

James Rodríguez could depart Bayern Munich with his management trying to force through a move for the Colombian, according to Sport Bild journalist Christian Falk.

However, it’s believed that things could change if the 27-year-old gets more playing time after the winter break. So far this season, Rodríguez has been seen as a fringe player, with the playmaker making eight appearances in the Bundesliga.

Juventus are being tipped as ‘frontrunners’ for Rodríguez’ signature after Bayern have cooled their interest in signing the player permanently.

https://www.getfootballnewsgermany.com/2019/james-rodriguez-entourage-are-pushing-for-a-transfer-away-from-bayern-munich/

Flamengo in talks to sign Bayern Munich defender Rafinha

Brazilian side Flamengo are in advanced negotiations to sign Rafinha as the 33-year-old looks set to leave Bayern Munich in the summer, according to Sky Sports journalist Max Bielefeld.

The right-back has also recently caught the attention of Sao Paulo and Internacional – who have both enquired about the Brazilian.

Rafinha has featured 15 times so far this season for Bayern, but it seems his talents are desired elsewhere with Bayern seemingly happy to let the defender return back to his homeland.

https://www.getfootballnewsgermany.com/2019/flamengo-in-talks-to-sign-bayern-munich-defender-rafinha/

Phaëton arrived at the Ligue 1 side from Brest a year ago and made his debut professional appearance against Nantes last November, but the recent signing of striker Alexandre Mendy is calling into question the player’s future in the 1st team and he is no longer training with the main group.

Negotiations over a professional contract are ongoing with the player and the idea of him being loaned out immediately after signing is currently being discussed, with Le Havre and Clermont having enquired to that effect.

Guingamp have responded to the two English clubs interested in Phaëton that a transfer would be impossible, but the media outlet believes that a bid of €800k could be enough to make EAG consider a sale. Before joining Guingamp, Phaëton was close to a move to Juventus.

BARELLA TO THE BRIDGE?

Chelsea have an interest in Cagliari midfielder Nicolo Barella, according to Sky sources.

Barella, who could cost Chelsea as much as £45million, is a possible replacement for Cesc Fabregas, who manager Maurizio Sarri has advised to leave Stamford Bridge in January.

Italy international Barella is under contract at Cagliari until 2022.

ABRAHAM SET FOR WOLVES

Chelsea look set to loan Tammy Abraham to Wolves, according to Sky sources.

The striker, who has spent the first half of this season on loan at Aston Villa, could be signed in time to feature in Wolves’ Monday Night Football clash with Manchester City.

Abraham has scored 16 goals in 20 games on loan at Aston Villa this season - but parent club Chelsea have a recall clause.

Chelsea do not want to sell the striker in this January window - but are keen for him to gain Premier League experience.
